column1: Vilyuchinsk (Russian: Вилючинск) is a closed town in Kamchatka Krai
column3: located on the Kamchatka Peninsula about 20 kilometers (12 mi) across Avacha Bay from Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky. Population: 22

column1: It was founded as Sovetsky (Сове́тский) on October 16
column2: 1968 through the amalgamation of three earlier settlements which supplied the Soviet Navy and served as a base for submarine construction: Rybachy
column5: as with other closed towns in the Soviet Union
column6: it was given a code name based on the nearest major city
column7: becoming known officially as Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky-50 until 1994. In 1994
column8: the town was renamed after the nearby volcano

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: it is incorporated as Vilyuchinsk Town Under Krai Jurisdiction—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the districts. As a municipal division
column3: Vilyuchinsk Town Under Krai Jurisdiction is incorporated as Vilyuchinsky Urban Okrug.

column1: Besides the construction of nuclear submarines
column2: the town's economy is largely reliant on fishing and processing of fish. In the suburb of Rybachy
column3: one of the three original settlements from which the town was created
column4: a squadron of submarines of the Russian Pacific Fleet has been based since August 1938. The local ship-repair industry began to develop in late 1959.

column1: Despite plans for the navy base to be closed in 2003 due to lack of finances
column2: this has continued to operate. The base had been modernized in the late 2000s with newly constructed residential buildings
column5: and a sports center with a water park opened in 2007 personally by President Vladimir Putin.

column1: Two Russian Orthodox churches were built in the 1990s
